awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG Improving Community and Neighborhood Safety through Open Data Collection
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this planning grant proposal is to study how data obtained by members of the public through camera pictures, video feeds and similar technology can be used to improve public safety without unduly infringing on personal rights such as privacy. To date, this effort has been driven by governments, through CCTV and similar technology, or private companies, through devices such as doorbell cameras. In contrast, this proposal will focus on how public safety can be enhanced through the use of data that are obtained and contributed voluntarily by individuals and are publicly maintained. For example, individuals might choose to capture the license plate identifiers of the automobiles that drive through their streets. The community might then agree to share this information with policing agencies seeking to track down stolen vehicles, reckless driving, or other criminal activities. As these examples illustrate, this arrangement raises significant questions about surveillance, trust, and privacy. This project aims to study these issues from multiple perspectives—technological, historical, and legal—with the aim of developing a workable and publicly vetted approach to concerns around privacy and public safety raised by recent commercial and technological developments.

This proposal addresses a new and burgeoning phenomenon. Closed circuit TV and public webcams have been available for decades, and people have used cell phone cameras on a massive scale for at least a decade. Much newer, however, is the increasing integration of such sensor capabilities in a wider set of environments, such as doorbell cameras. Newer still is the idea that this integration could be crowdsourced to the public rather than controlled by private companies. This project will study these societal issues from the following perspectives: (1) technology, including a survey of low-cost embedded devices that are suitable for collecting, encrypting, transmitting, and storing data from personally accessible devices; (2) data privacy, in which this project will appraise the protocols that might manage how these data are secured, stored, and kept private, including a characterization of anonymization methodologies; (3) historical, in which this project will review and analyze past episodes of public data collection and public safety, with the aim of determining how this history can provide guides for our current work; (4) legal, including a review of various state and federal statutes, as well as Fourth Amendment jurisprudence, with the goal of analyzing how the law might govern this type of information collection and storage; (5) safety, where this project will address the effect public data collection and dissemination of the type proposed can have on public safety.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this planning grant was to study how data obtained by members of the public can use camera pictures, video feeds and similar technology to improve public safety without unduly infringing on personal rights such as privacy. To date, this effort has been driven by governments, through CCTV and similar technology, or private companies, through devices such as doorbell cameras. In contrast, our project focused on how public safety can be enhanced through the use of data that are obtained and contributed voluntarily by individuals and are publicly maintained.

During this project we engaged in a number of empirical and technical activities. The empirical activities were aimed at understanding how technology is currently used in neighborhoods and gathering the viewpoints of residents with regard to those technologies. The technical activities centered around building a prototype open data collection framework informed by the empirical findings.

While we were interested in studying all types of neighborhood technology, we primarily focused on public safety technologies. In particular, we examined the use of automated license plate readers (ALPR), which consist of cameras that take pictures of license plates combined with computer software that turns the images into alphanumeric characters; police usage of ALPR includes software that compares the captured plates against a "hot list" of license plates. We examined ALPR in detail for three reasons. First, the Nashville Metropolitan Council was in the process of considering various ALPR-related ordinances, which ranged from a total ban to usage with restrictions; this gave us an opportunity to work with the city to study the social issues. Second, the technology has recently become available to the public, giving us an opportunity to speak with groups and individuals about their first-hand experiences with the technology. Third, research studies and civil-liberty groups have questioned whether the government use of ALPR violates an individual's right to privacy, giving us an opportunity to delve into the privacy-related issues of technology.

Our empirical activities were both qualitative and quantitative. They included meetings with and presentations to the Nashville Metropolitan City Council, a survey on technology with approximately 1000 responses, two focus groups with current and former neighborhood leaders, conversations with and presentations to homeowner associations, a meeting with a local police precinct, and numerous internal discussions.

Our interactions with the city council centered on Nashville's proposed use of ALPR and the debate on whether the city and police should be permitted to use ALPR. We presented ALPR-literature surveys to the council, consulted on how ALPR had been and might be regulated, and heard viewpoints on ALPR and privacy from the chief of police, the district attorney, public defenders, the community oversight board, council members, and representatives from the ACLU; these meetings were valuable in understanding the nuanced views towards ALPR, and more generally, privacy and technology. We also presented the core idea of this planning grant which, again, is that a new model of data governance, publicly contributed and publicly maintained, could provide unique benefits over a publicly contributed but privately maintained model of data governance, particularly for ALPR-related data.

As part of our interaction with the city council, we ran a non-random sample survey, open to anyone in Nashville, to gather opinions on ALPR. The survey included two free-form questions asking participants to explain why they were in favor of ALPR, or why they opposed ALPR. After coding the responses, we found three primary themes from those opposed to ALPR. The first was trust: those opposed cited a lack of trust in the government. The second was privacy: those opposed did not want a "big brother" regime. The third was 4th Amendment Jurisprudence: those opposed stated that ALPR use could be an unreasonable search.

Our two focus groups with neighborhood leaders revealed that the participating neighborhoods used technologies such as Nextdoor, Facebook groups, and Ring cameras. Participants reported that viewing data on Nextdoor and Facebook groups was difficult, particularly because posts often disappear after one day. When asked about neighborhood data collection, and in particular data on public safety, such as ALPR data, a recurring theme was that the community should control the data and that the police should be involved only when absolutely necessary.

Our technical activities included the development of a prototype open data collection software framework. The goal was to design it so that the social expectations, such as privacy and data retention policies, were guaranteed by the technical implementation. The current prototype consists of a backend component that stores data and a frontend component used to view and interact with data; both are available on GitHub under an open source license.

In conclusion, our findings indicate that there is a societal need for open data collection models that operate in a publicly-contributed and publicly-maintained fashion. We plan to continue our investigations in the future.
